Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellows: Sustainable Development of Shale-gas Resources in Pennsylvania - Bridging Science, Policy and Economics of Hydraulic Fracturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will address two questions related to the regulation and economics of shale-gas development: 1) How would inclusion of hydraulic fracturing of shale-gas formations under the federal Safe Drinking Water Act impact shale-gas production activities and risks of fresh water contamination? 2) What are the comparative long-term costs and benefits of the hydraulic fracturing of shale-gas reservoirs compared to other energy development strategies? The approach will combine comparative policy analysis with an economic assessment of the environmental externalities and opportunity costs associated with the hydraulic fracturing of shale-gas reservoirs. The goal is to develop an approach for choosing regulations that minimize risk to the environment while allowing for robust development of shale-gas reserves.

Recent advances in directional drilling have made unconventional extraction of natural gas from organic-rich shale formations economically viable. The state of Pennsylvania serves as a prime case study for sustainable shale-gas development because it is underlain by one of the most promising shale-gas reservoirs in the United States, the Marcellus Shale. The rapid investment in shale-gas extraction by the oil and gas industry has outpaced the development of regulatory policy designed to handle the unique environmental challenges associated with extensive hydraulic fracturing activities. The assessments to be carried out in this project will help guide the development of sound regulatory policy that will ensure the security of fresh water resources and the safety of citizens in close proximity to extraction wells.

This project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. With SEES Fellows support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish themselves in an independent research career related to sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to examine long-term costs and benefits associated with hydraulic fracturing of shale gas reservoirs in comparison with other energy development strategies. Three main avenues of research were pursued: (1) investigation of regional-scale waste management strategies for sustainable shale gas development; (2) life cycle assessment of the human toxicity impact (HTI) of environmental emissions associated with coal-fired vs. shale-gas electric power generation; and (3) evaluation of Michigan’s high volume water withdrawal online screening tool as it pertains to permitting groundwater withdrawals for hydraulic fracturing activities.

 

Efforts to evaluate regional-scale approaches for improved management of wastewater and co-produced gases sought to identify opportunities to reduce the environmental footprint of shale resource production through economically viable strategies. This research effort predicted development trends in natural gas production through 2030 as a platform to discuss the innovative repurposing of two concomitant byproducts: wastewater generated during flowback and production, and CO2 removed in gas processing. Specific strategies were examined for the Marcellus shale in Pennsylvania, where mature oil fields offer a low-cost and potentially profitable repository for wastewater, and unconventional oil and gas fields in eastern Texas, where CO2 removed from Haynesville shale gas could be combined with natural gas co-produced with tight oil in the Eagle Ford for enhanced oil recovery. Because effective deployment of such strategies hinges on appropriate policy, efforts were also made to consider how state-level adoption and promotion of carbon capture utilization and storage incentives for similar reuse chains can reduce the footprint of shale gas development with appreciable economic benefits.

 

The relative human toxicity impact (HTI) of electricity produced from shale gas and coal were compared to better understand how increased penetration of shale gas will affect overall toxic releases associated with the power sector. A life cycle assessment (LCA) model was developed for this analysis and a scenario-based analysis was used to evaluate different environmental release scenarios and associated negative impact on human health. HTI is commonly used within LCA to quantify the inherent toxicity burden associated with emissions from a product or process and is measured as disability adjusted life years per unit of electricity generation (DALY/GWh). The results of the comparative analysis indicated that electricity produced from shale gas has a lower HTI than electricity produced from coal. This was true across all scenarios examined, including conservative estimates of emissions from coal relative to those from natural gas electricity. Key factors that make coal have a higher HTI include its associated emissions of particulate matter, mercury, and arsenic. Although translation of HTI into actual human health effects can only be obtained through a more detailed risk assessment, the results of this analysis indicate that substituting natural gas for coal will reduce the overall toxicity burden of the power sector.

 

The State of Michigan uses an online screening tool (the Water Withdrawal Assessment Tool, WWAT) to help permit high volume groundwater withdrawals and this tool has been used to permit water wells used for hydraulic fracturing completions in Michigan. The groundwater component of the WWAT uses an analytical solution to predict reductions in groundwater baseflow to the stream (and subsequent stream flow reductions) due to nearby pumping events. To assess the tool’s performance, this study compared calculations for streamflow depletion estimated using the Hunt (1999) solution, as implemented in the WWAT, with those of a numerical groundwater flow model developed in MODFLOW for two different locations in Michigan where high volume groundwater withdrawal wells were permitted. The results showed that the WWAT, in general, provides a conservative estimate of stream depletion.  However, to obtain a more accurate estimate, the type of aquifer (unconfined versus semi-confined) needs to be taken into account.  The most critical parameters were found to be the storativity and the streambed conductance.  Since storativity has a fixed value of 0.01 in the WWAT, the role of streambed conductance in determining the estimated streamflow reduction is paramount and better estimates of this parameter are needed.
